oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aerial photograph of interstate construction in North Nashville near Jefferson Street, ca. 1968
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Aerial photograph of a portion of North Nashville, in the Jefferson Street area, looking west, circa 1968, taken by Metro Photographer, William M. King. The future route of Interstate 40 is apparent in the areas of cleared ground that run to the west and then turn to the southwest. Predominant roads running toward the west are Jefferson Street and Scovel Street. Two large buildings at middle left are located on the campus of Fisk University. The larger building, with dormers and narrow chimneys visible on the roofline, is Jubilee Hall. The L-shaped building just behind it is Crosthwaite Hall. Just beyond Fisk, to the west, can be seen a building on the Meharry Medical College campus. In the distance, just before the curve of the interstate to the left, can be seen a railroad bridge of the Tennessee Central crossing Jefferson Street. Numerous buildings along Jefferson Street are visible in the foreground and middle distance. Residential areas to the north along Scovel Street and Heiman Street are also visible. Lee Chapel AME church can be seen near the middle of Scovel Street, marking the intersection of 18th Avenue North. In the far distance in the upper right hand corner is the vicinity of Tennessee State University. Forms part of the Nashville Room Historic Photographs Collection. 1 photograph : b & w ; 8 x 10 in.

This portion of Jefferson Street, close to the campuses of Fisk University, Meharry Medical College, and Tennessee State University, was the center of black life and culture in Nashville at this time. The construction of the interstate destroyed significant portions of this important social and cultural hub, as well as many parts of the nearby neighborhood. This photograph reveals just how extensive and disruptive the route of the interstate was to this African American community in Nashville. Interstate 40 would pass through this location when it was built between 1968 and 1971. It joined Interstate 265 in a major interchange near this location, composing the northwest portion of the downtown inner loop. In 2000, Interstate 265 ceased to exist, and was redesignated as part of Interstate 65.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Lee Chapel African Methodist Episcopal Church (Nashville, Tenn.); Fisk University; Meharry Medical College; Tennessee State University
